## Domain Model

- Kern-Entitaeten: Nutzer/Besucher, Feature, Anforderung und Iteration.
- Beziehungen: Eine Anforderung aggregiert Features; jede Iteration verfeinert bestehende Features und kann neue ueber ein strukturiertes Delta hinzufuegen.
- Datenkonsistenz: Feature-IDs bleiben ueber Iterationen stabil und gelten als unveraenderliche Kennungen.
- Quellkontext (Iteration 1): Erstelle eine einfache Landingpage fuer ein lokales Yogastudio mit Hero, Leistungen, Kursplan, Kontaktformular und Impressum. Fokus auf klare Struktur und testbare Akzeptanzkriterien.

## Global Business Rules

- Bestehende Features duerfen waehrend der iterativen Verfeinerung nicht entfernt werden.
- Neue Features werden nur ueber validiertes Feature-Delta-JSON akzeptiert.
- Doppelte Features (gleiche Intention/Bezeichnung) werden deterministisch verworfen.
- Akzeptanzkriterien aller Features muessen testbar und beobachtbar bleiben.

## Functional Feature Catalogue

- Runtime: Node.js-Service mit Endpunkten fuer den iterativen Compiler.
- Umgebung: Dockerisierte Local/Dev-Ausfuehrung mit reproduzierbarem Build und Health-Endpoint.
- Abhaengigkeiten: LLM-Provider-Integration mit Model-Fallback-Strategie.
- Auslieferung: Aenderungen werden mit TypeScript-Check und End-to-End-API-Smoke-Run validiert.

### F-01: ### Feature Name: Hero-Sektion

### Feature ID: F-01
### Feature Name: Hero-Sektion

1. **Zweck** — Die Hero-Sektion fungiert als erster visueller Kontaktpunkt. Sie vermittelt die Studio-Atmosphäre, die Kernbotschaft und animiert Nutzende zur Interaktion (z. B. Kursplan ansehen, Kontakt aufnehmen).

2. **Akteure** — Besucherinnen und Besucher der Webseite

3. **Auslöser** — Aufruf der Landingpage (automatisches Laden beim Seitenaufruf)

4. **Vorbedingungen** — Webseite ist geladen, alle Assets (Bild, Text) sind verfügbar

5. **Hauptfluss**
   - 1. Die Seite wird geladen; die Hero-Sektion erscheint im oberen Bereich (above the fold).
   - 2. Ein Hintergrundbild (Studio-Atmosphäre oder ruhige Yoga-Szene) wird angezeigt.
   - 3. Eine Überschrift (z. B. „Willkommen bei [Studio-Name] – Dein Yoga-Studio in [Stadt]") wird dargestellt.
   - 4. Ein Untertitel beschreibt das Angebot kurz (z. B. „Entspannung, Bewegung und inneres Gleichgewicht").
   - 5. Ein primärer Call-to-Action-Button („Kurse entdecken") verlinkt zum Kursplan.
   - 6. Ein sekundärer Call-to-Action-Button („Kontakt") verlinkt zum Kontaktformular.

6. **Alternative Flüsse**
   - Wenn das Hintergrundbild nicht geladen wird, wird eine Hintergrundfarbe angezeigt (Fallback).
   - Wenn JavaScript deaktiviert ist, bleibt die Hero-Sektion funktional (CSS-only Darstellung).

7. **Nachbedingungen** — Die Hero-Sektion ist vollständig sichtbar; Buttons sind klickbar und verweisen auf die entsprechenden Seitenbereiche.

8. **Datenimpact** — Keine Daten werden gespeichert oder verarbeitet.

9. **UI-Impact** — Neuer Bereich im oberen Seitenbereich; responsives Layout mit Anpassung für Mobile (kleinere Schriftgrößen, zentrierter Text).

10. **Akzeptanzkriterien**
    - [ ] Die Hero-Sektion füllt den gesamten sichtbaren Bereich beim ersten Laden (100vh oder mindestens 500px Höhe).
    - [ ] Das Hintergrundbild wird innerhalb von 2 Sekunden geladen oder es erscheint ein Fallback.
    - [ ] Beide CTA-Buttons sind sichtbar und führen zu den korrekten Anker-Links.
    - [ ] Auf Mobile-Geräten (≤768px) ist der Text lesbar und die Buttons gut erreichbar (mindestens 44x44px Touch-Target).
    - [ ] Die Seite ist WCAG 2.1 AA konform (ausreichender Kontrast zwischen Text und Hintergrund).

### F-02: Services Overview Section

1. Purpose
The purpose of the Services Overview Section is to inform website visitors about the yoga offerings available at the studio. This section displays a curated list of services with titles and descriptions, enabling potential customers to understand the studio's value proposition and determine which offerings align with their needs. The section serves as a key conversion element by presenting the services in a clear, scannable format that encourages visitors to consider booking a course or contacting the studio.

2. Actors
- **Primary Actor**: Website Visitor (potential yoga student)
- **Secondary Actor**: Content Administrator (studio owner or staff who manages the website content)

3. Trigger
The Services Overview Section is rendered when the landingpage completes loading in the user's browser. The section becomes visible when the user scrolls down from the Hero section or when the page is displayed on a viewport that naturally shows the Services section above the fold.

4. Preconditions
- The landingpage HTML structure must be fully loaded
- The services data (titles, descriptions, optional images) must be available in the application state or loaded from a data source
- CSS styles for the Services section must be applied
- The viewport must support rendering of the section layout

5. Main Flow

**Step 1**: Initialize the Services Overview Section container
- Create a section element with the ID `services` and class `services-section`
- Set the section background color to `#F9F5F0` (warm off-white)
- Set the section padding to `80px 20px` (vertical, horizontal)

**Step 2**: Create section header
- Create a heading element (h2) with text content "Unsere Leistungen"
- Apply font family "Playfair Display", font size `42px`, color `#2D2A26`
- Center-align the heading
- Add a decorative underline element: 60px width, 3px height, color `#BFA67A` (warm gold)
- Position the underline 16px below the heading text

**Step 3**: Create services grid container
- Create a div element with class `services-grid`
- Set display to `grid`
- Set grid template columns to `repeat(auto-fit, minmax(300px, 1fr))`
- Set gap to `40px`
- Set max-width to `1200px` and margin `0 auto`

**Step 4**: Define service card structure
- Create individual service card elements with class `service-card`
- Set background to `#FFFFFF`
- Set border-radius to `12px`
- Set box-shadow: `0 4px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.06)`
- Set padding to `32px`
- Set transition to `transform 0.3s ease, box-shadow 0.3s ease`

**Step 5**: Populate service card content
- For each service, render:
  - Icon container (if applicable): 56px × 56px, background `#F9F5F0`, border-radius `50%`, margin-bottom `20px`
  - Service title (h3): font-family "Playfair Display", font-size `24px`, color `#2D2A26`, margin-bottom `12px`
  - Service description (p): font-family "Lato", font-size `16px`, line-height `1.6`, color `#5C5A56`

**Step 6**: Render service data
- Load and iterate through the services array containing 4 default services:
  1. Hatha Yoga: "Sanfte Körperarbeit für Anfänger und Fortgeschrittene. Improve flexibility and inner peace through traditional postures."
  2. Vinyasa Flow: "Dynamischer Yoga-Stil mit fließenden Bewegungen. Synchronize breath with movement for increased strength."
  3. Yin Yoga: "Tiefenentspannung mit lang gehaltenen Positionen. Release tension and improve joint mobility."
  4. Privatstunden: "Individuelle Betreuung für deine persönliche Praxis. Customized sessions tailored to your needs."

**Step 7**: Apply hover effects
- On service-card hover: translateY(-8px), box-shadow `0 12px 32px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.12)`
- Ensure smooth transition animation

**Step 8**: Make section responsive
- At viewport width ≤ 768px:
  - Reduce heading font-size to `32px`
  - Reduce grid gap to `24px`
  - Adjust card padding to `24px`
  - Set grid template columns to `1fr` (single column)
- At viewport width ≤ 480px:
  - Reduce heading font-size to `28px`
  - Adjust card padding to `20px`

6. Alternate Flows

**Alternate Flow 1: No Services Data Available**
- If the services array is empty or undefined, render a placeholder message
- Display text: "Unsere Leistungen werden bald verfügbar sein." (Our services will be available soon)
- Style the placeholder with the same heading structure but with reduced opacity (`0.6`)
- Log a warning to the console for debugging purposes

**Alternate Flow 2: Service Card Image Fails to Load**
- If an optional service image fails to load (404 error or network failure)
- Display a fallback icon from a predefined icon set
- The fallback icon should be a yoga pose silhouette in color `#BFA67A`
- No error message should be visible to the user

**Alternate Flow 3: Partial Service Data**
- If only some service fields are present (e.g., title exists but description is missing)
- Render the available fields
- Display "Beschreibung folgt" (Description coming soon) for missing descriptions
- Ensure layout remains unbroken

**Alternate Flow 4: JavaScript Disabled**
- If JavaScript is disabled in the browser
- The section should still be visible with static HTML content
- Services data should be hardcoded in the initial HTML response
- Hover effects are gracefully degraded (no animation)

7. Postconditions
- The Services Overview Section is fully rendered and visible on the landingpage
- All 4 service cards are displayed in a responsive grid layout
- Each service card contains a title and description
- Hover interactions are functional on desktop devices
- The section is properly spaced from adjacent sections (Hero above, Kursplan below)
- All typography and colors match the specified design system

8. Data Impact
- **Input Data**: Services data array containing objects with the following fields:
  - `id`: Unique identifier (string/integer)
  - `title`: Service name (string, max 50 characters)
  - `description`: Service description (string, max 200 characters)
  - `icon`: Optional icon identifier (string)
- **Data Source**: Hardcoded in JavaScript or loaded from a local JSON file (`services.json`)
- **No Persistent Storage**: Data is client-side only for this feature

9. UI Impact
- **New Section Added**: The Services Overview Section is inserted between the Hero Section (F-01) and the Kursplan Section (F-03)
- **Layout Disruption**: None; the section integrates seamlessly into the existing page flow
- **Visual Changes**:
  - Background color change from Hero background to Services section background
  - New typography hierarchy introduced (h2 heading, h3 subheadings)
  - Grid layout applied for service cards
- **Interaction Changes**: New hover states introduced on service cards

10. Acceptance Criteria

**AC-01**: When the landingpage loads, the Services Overview Section is visible below the Hero section
- Verification: Navigate to the landingpage URL, scroll down, confirm the section with heading "Unsere Leistungen" is displayed

**AC-02**: Exactly 4 service cards are displayed in the services grid
- Verification: Count the number of elements with class `service-card`; the count must equal 4

**AC-03**: Each service card displays a title matching the expected values (Hatha Yoga, Vinyasa Flow, Yin Yoga, Privatstunden)
- Verification: Query all h3 elements within `.service-card` and verify text content matches the four expected titles

**AC-04**: Each service card displays a non-empty description
- Verification: Query all p elements within `.service-card`, confirm no element has empty textContent

**AC-05**: Service cards are arranged in a responsive grid (3+ columns on desktop, 2 on tablet, 1 on mobile)
- Verification: Resize browser viewport to 1200px+ width, confirm grid shows appropriate columns; resize to 768px and 480px, confirm layout adapts

**AC-06**: Hovering over a service card triggers the translateY animation
- Verification: Use browser DevTools to simulate hover on a `.service-card` element, confirm computed transform includes translateY

**AC-07**: Typography matches specification (Playfair Display for headings, Lato for body text)
- Verification: Inspect computed font-family on h2, h3, and p elements within the section

**AC-08**: Section spacing is correct (80px vertical padding)
- Verification: Inspect computed padding on `.services-section` element

**AC-09**: Color scheme is applied correctly (warm off-white background, gold accents)
- Verification: Inspect computed background-color on `.services-section` and border-color on decorative underline element

**AC-10**: The page passes accessibility basic checks (section has proper heading hierarchy, sufficient color contrast)
- Verification: Use accessibility audit tool to verify heading order (h2 followed by h3) and contrast ratio exceeds 4.5:1 for text

### F-03: Course Schedule Display

1. Purpose
The Course Schedule Display feature presents a structured overview of all available yoga classes at the studio. It enables website visitors to view scheduled classes organized by day of the week, including class name and time. The feature serves as a key information resource for potential customers evaluating the studio's offerings.

2. Actors
- **Primary Actor**: Website Visitor (potential yoga student browsing the landing page)
- **Secondary Actor**: Studio Administrator (maintains course data through the content management system)

3. Trigger
The Course Schedule Display is triggered when:
- The user navigates to the schedule section via internal anchor link on the landing page
- The user loads the landing page and scrolls to the schedule section
- The user directly accesses the schedule page via URL

4. Preconditions
- The landing page is fully loaded in the user's browser
- The schedule data has been configured in the content management system
- The user's device has an active internet connection
- The schedule section is visible in the viewport or about to become visible

5. Main Flow (numbered deterministic steps)
1. User navigates to or scrolls to the course schedule section on the landing page
2. The browser initiates a request to retrieve schedule data from the local JSON data source
3. The system loads the course data array containing objects with properties: `id`, `day`, `time`, `className`, `duration`, `instructor`
4. The system sorts the course data chronologically by day (Monday through Sunday) and then by start time
5. The system groups the courses by day of the week
6. The system renders a table or card-based layout for each day containing all courses for that day
7. Each course entry displays: class name (bold), time in 24-hour format (HH:MM), duration in minutes, and instructor name
8. The system displays the current week dates or a general "weekly schedule" header
9. The rendered schedule becomes visible in the designated schedule section container
10. A subtle fade-in animation plays to reveal the schedule content

6. Alternate Flows

**Alternate Flow 1: Empty Schedule State**
- Steps 2-3: System detects that the course data array is empty or contains no valid entries
- Step 4: System displays a friendly message: "Der Kursplan wird in Kürze veröffentlicht." (The schedule will be published soon.)
- Step 5: Display includes a contact button linking to the contact section

**Alternate Flow 2: Data Loading Error**
- Steps 2-3: System encounters a network error or data parsing failure
- Step 4: System displays an error message: "Der Kursplan konnte nicht geladen werden. Bitte versuchen Sie es später erneut."
- Step 5: System provides a manual "Erneut laden" (Reload) button

**Alternate Flow 3: Single-Day Filter**
- Step 1: User clicks on a day tab or filter control above the schedule
- Step 2: System filters the course array to show only courses matching the selected day
- Step 3: System re-renders the schedule displaying only the selected day's courses
- Step 4: User can click "Alle Tage" (All days) to reset the filter

7. Postconditions
- The course schedule is visible and displays all scheduled yoga classes with day, time, and class name
- The schedule is correctly organized: courses appear chronologically within each day
- The layout is responsive and readable on both desktop and mobile viewports
- If data is unavailable, an appropriate message is displayed instead of broken UI
- The user can view the complete weekly offering without requiring additional actions

8. Data Impact
- **Data Structure**: Course schedule is stored as a JSON array with the following schema:
```json
[
  {
    "id": "string (unique identifier)",
    "day": "string (Monday|Tuesday|Wednesday|Thursday|Friday|Saturday|Sunday)",
    "time": "string (HH:MM format)",
    "duration": "number (minutes)",
    "className": "string",
    "instructor": "string"
  }
]
```
- **Storage Location**: Local JSON file (`schedule.json`) loaded at runtime or embedded directly in the page JavaScript
- **Data Size**: Maximum 50 course entries supported without pagination

9. UI Impact
- **Layout**: Schedule section occupies full-width container with maximum width of 1200px, centered
- **Visual Structure**: Day headers (h3) followed by course list for each day
- **Course Item Display**: Card or table row with left-aligned time, bold class name, and small instructor text
- **Responsive Breakpoints**:
  - Desktop (≥1024px): Multi-column layout showing 2-3 days per row
  - Tablet (768px-1023px): Two days per row
  - Mobile (<768px): Single column, vertically stacked days
- **Color Scheme**: Uses studio's primary color for day headers, neutral text color for course details
- **Typography**: Sans-serif font, 16px base size, 14px for metadata (time, instructor)

10. Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Schedule displays on page load within 2 seconds of the section becoming visible
- [ ] Each course entry shows class name, time (HH:MM format), and instructor name
- [ ] Courses are grouped by day and sorted chronologically within each day
- [ ] Schedule is visible without horizontal scrolling on all viewport sizes (320px minimum)
- [ ] Empty state displays appropriate message when no courses are configured
- [ ] Error state displays retry option if data fails to load
- [ ] All text is in German language
- [ ] Schedule section has a distinct visual heading: "Kursplan" or "Wochenplan"
- [ ] No console errors appear when the schedule loads
- [ ] Accessibility: Day headers use proper heading hierarchy (h3), course times are in a machine-readable format where possible

### F-04: ### Feature Name: Kontaktformular

### Feature ID: F-04
### Feature Name: Kontaktformular

1. **Zweck** — Das Kontaktformular ermöglicht es Interessierten, eine Nachricht an das Yogastudio zu senden. Es dient der Lead-Generierung und Kundenkommunikation.

2. **Akteure** — Besucherinnen und Besucher der Webseite

3. **Auslöser** — Ausfüllen und Absenden des Formulars

4. **Vorbedingungen** — Formularseite ist geladen; alle Formularfelder sind verfügbar.

5. **Hauptfluss**
   - 1. Das Kontaktformular wird angezeigt.
   - 2. Folgende Felder sind vorhanden: Name (Pflichtfeld), E-Mail-Adresse (Pflichtfeld), Telefonnummer (optional), Nachricht (Pflichtfeld).
   - 3. Der Nutzende füllt die Felder aus.
   - 4. Der Nutzende klickt auf „Absenden".
   - 5. Client-seitige Validierung prüft Pflichtfelder und E-Mail-Format.
   - 6. Bei erfolgreicher Validierung wird das Formular an den E-Mail-Service gesendet.
   - 7. Eine Erfolgsmeldung wird angezeigt: „Vielen Dank! Ihre Nachricht wurde gesendet."
   - 8. Das Formular wird zurückgesetzt.

6. **Alternative Flänge**
   - Wenn Pflichtfelder fehlen, werden Fehlermeldungen unter den entsprechenden Feldern angezeigt.
   - Wenn die E-Mail-Adresse ungültig ist, wird eine spezifische Fehlermeldung angezeigt.
   - Wenn der E-Mail-Service nicht erreichbar ist, wird eine Fehlermeldung angezeigt: „Nachricht konnte nicht gesendet werden. Bitte kontaktieren Sie uns telefonisch."
   - Wenn JavaScript deaktiviert ist, wird das Formular an eine serverseitige URL weitergeleitet (Fallback).

7. **Nachbedingungen** — Formulardaten wurden gesendet; Erfolgs- oder Fehlermeldung ist sichtbar.

8. **Datenimpact** — Formulardaten werden an einen externen E-Mail-Service (z. B. Formspree) übertragen und dort verarbeitet. Keine Speicherung auf der Landingpage selbst.

9. **UI-Impact** — Neue Sektion unter Kursplan; Formular mit Eingabefeldern und Absenden-Button.

10. **Akzeptanzkriterien**
    - [ ] Alle Pflichtfelder sind mit einem Sternchen (*) gekennzeichnet.
    - [ ] Bei leerem Pflichtfeld wird eine sichtbare Fehlermeldung angezeigt.
    - [ ] Bei ungültiger E-Mail-Adresse wird eine spezifische Fehlermeldung angezeigt.
    - [ ] Nach erfolgreichem Absenden erscheint eine Bestätigungsmeldung.
    - [ ] Das Formular ist responsiv und auf Mobile-Geräten bedienbar.
    - [ ] Ein Datenschutzhinweis-Link ist vorhanden und verlinkt auf die Datenschutz-Sektion.

### F-05: Contact Form Submission

1. Purpose
The contact form submission feature enables website visitors to send inquiries to the yoga studio. It captures visitor contact information and message content, validates the input, stores the submission in the backend database, and triggers confirmation emails to both the visitor and the studio administrator. This facilitates lead generation and customer communication.

2. Actors
- Website Visitor: Fills out and submits the contact form
- Studio Administrator: Receives notification email with form submission data

3. Trigger
The feature is triggered when a website visitor clicks the "Absenden" (Submit) button on the contact form after completing all required fields.

4. Preconditions
- Contact form page is accessible and fully loaded
- All required form fields (name, email, message) are rendered in the DOM
- Backend API endpoint /api/contact exists and responds to POST requests
- Email service configuration is set for sending transactional emails
- Database table "contact_submissions" exists with required schema

5. Main Flow

1. Visitor navigates to the contact page at /kontakt
2. Visitor enters text into the "Name" input field (required)
3. Visitor enters text into the "E-Mail" input field (required)
4. Visitor enters text into the "Telefon" input field (optional)
5. Visitor selects an option from the "Betreff" dropdown menu (optional): "Allgemeine Anfrage", "Kursanmeldung", "Probestunde", "Sonstiges"
6. Visitor enters text into the "Nachricht" textarea field (required)
7. Visitor clicks the "Absenden" button
8. JavaScript validation executes: checks that "Name" field contains at least 2 characters
9. JavaScript validation executes: checks that "E-Mail" field matches email regex pattern
10. JavaScript validation executes: checks that "Nachricht" field contains at least 10 characters
11. If any validation fails, JavaScript displays inline error messages under respective fields and stops execution
12. If validation passes, JavaScript disables the submit button and shows a loading indicator
13. JavaScript sends HTTP POST request to endpoint /api/contact with JSON payload containing: name, email, phone, subject, message, timestamp
14. Backend receives POST request at /api/contact
15. Backend validates request payload: ensures all required fields are present and non-empty
16. Backend sanitizes all string inputs using HTML entity encoding to prevent XSS attacks
17. Backend validates email format using RFC 5322 compliant regex
18. Backend inserts a new record into the "contact_submissions" table with columns: id (UUID), name, email, phone, subject, message, created_at (UTC timestamp), status (default: "new")
19. Database returns successful insert confirmation with the new record ID
20. Backend triggers asynchronous email to visitor's email address with subject "Ihre Anfrage an das Yoga Studio" containing form submission confirmation
21. Backend triggers asynchronous email to studio administrator at admin@yogastudio.local with subject "Neue Kontaktanfrage" containing full submission details
22. Backend returns HTTP 200 status code with JSON response: { "success": true, "message": "Nachricht erfolgreich gesendet", "submissionId": "<uuid>" }
23. Frontend receives HTTP 200 response
24. Frontend displays success message "Vielen Dank für Ihre Nachricht! Wir werden uns in Kürze bei Ihnen melden." in a green success banner
25. Frontend clears all form input fields
26. Frontend re-enables the submit button
27. Main flow ends

6. Alternate Flows

**Alternate Flow 1: Invalid Email Format**
1-11. Execute steps 1-11 from Main Flow
12. Visitor enters "invalid-email" in the E-Mail field
13. JavaScript validation fails email format check
14. JavaScript displays error message "Bitte geben Sie eine gültige E-Mail-Adresse ein" under the E-Mail field
15. Submit button remains enabled
16. Flow ends without form submission

**Alternate Flow 2: Backend Server Error**
1-13. Execute steps 1-13 from Main Flow
14. Backend encounters database connection failure
15. Backend returns HTTP 500 status code with JSON response: { "success": false, "message": "Ein Fehler ist aufgetreten. Bitte versuchen Sie es später erneut." }
16. Frontend displays error message in a red alert banner
17. Frontend retains all form data entered by visitor
18. Frontend re-enables the submit button
19. Flow ends

**Alternate Flow 3: Network Timeout**
1-13. Execute steps 1-13 from Main Flow
14. Request times out after 30 seconds due to network issues
15. Frontend catches timeout error
16. Frontend displays error message "Verbindung fehlgeschlagen. Bitte überprüfen Sie Ihre Internetverbindung und versuchen Sie es erneut."
17. Frontend retains all form data
18. Frontend re-enables the submit button
19. Flow ends

7. Postconditions
- New contact submission record exists in database with status "new"
- Confirmation email has been queued for delivery to the visitor's email address
- Notification email has been queued for delivery to the studio administrator
- Success message is visible on the contact page
- All form input fields are cleared (empty strings)
- Submit button is in enabled state

8. Data Impact
- New row created in "contact_submissions" table with columns:
  - id: UUID (primary key)
  - name: VARCHAR(255)
  - email: VARCHAR(255)
  - phone: VARCHAR(50), nullable
  - subject: VARCHAR(100), nullable
  - message: TEXT
  - created_at: DATETIME (UTC)
  - status: ENUM("new", "read", "responded")
- Email queue table receives two new entries for transactional emails

9. UI Impact
- Contact form section displays on the contact page with fields: Name (text input), E-Mail (email input), Telefon (tel input), Betreff (select dropdown), Nachricht (textarea), Absenden (submit button)
- Inline validation error messages appear below invalid fields in red color (#dc3545)
- Loading spinner (CSS animation) appears on submit button during submission
- Green success banner (#28a745 background) appears above form after successful submission
- Red error banner (#dc3545 background) appears above form on backend errors

10. Acceptance Criteria
- AC1: Form cannot be submitted when any required field (Name, E-Mail, Nachricht) is empty
- AC2: Form cannot be submitted when E-Mail field contains invalid format
- AC3: Successful submission returns HTTP 200 within 5 seconds on normal network conditions
- AC4: Database contains a new record with all submitted form data after successful submission
- AC5: Success message is displayed to the visitor within 2 seconds of receiving backend response
- AC6: All form fields are cleared immediately after successful submission
- AC7: Submit button is disabled during form submission to prevent double-submission
- AC8: Network timeout displays appropriate error message after 30 seconds
- AC9: Backend returns HTTP 500 with user-friendly message on server errors
- AC10: Form data is preserved when validation fails so visitor can correct input

### F-06: Imprint Display

1. Purpose
The Imprint Display feature ensures legal compliance by presenting the business's legal information required by German law (§ 5 TMG) and similar international regulations. It provides website visitors with transparent access to the studio's business identification, contact details, and legal responsibility information, establishing trust and meeting statutory requirements for commercial websites.

2. Actors
- **Primary Actor**: Website Visitor (prospective yoga student or customer)
- **Secondary Actor**: Website Administrator (content provider/maintainer)

3. Trigger
The feature is triggered when a user performs one of the following actions:
- Clicks the "Impressum" navigation link in the website footer
- Directly navigates to the imprint page via URL (e.g., /impressum)
- Scrolls to the imprint section if displayed inline on the homepage

4. Preconditions
- The imprint page or section exists within the website structure
- The imprint navigation link is present in the website footer
- All required legal fields contain valid, formatted content
- The website is deployed and accessible via HTTP/HTTPS

5. Main Flow (numbered deterministic steps)
1. User clicks the "Impressum" link in the website footer navigation
2. System receives the navigation request to the imprint route
3. System retrieves the imprint page template
4. System populates the template with stored imprint data fields:
   - Business name (required)
   - Business address (street, postal code, city, country)
   - Contact email address
   - Contact phone number
   - Commercial register information (if applicable)
   - VAT identification number (if applicable)
   - Managing director/responsible person name
   - Supervisory authority (if applicable)
5. System renders the imprint page with all legal content
6. System displays the rendered page to the user in the viewport

6. Alternate Flows

### F-05: Contact Form Submission

1. Purpose
The contact form submission feature enables website visitors to send inquiries to the yoga studio. It captures visitor contact information and message content, validates the input, stores the submission in the backend database, and triggers confirmation emails to both the visitor and the studio administrator. This facilitates lead generation and customer communication.

2. Actors
- Website Visitor: Fills out and submits the contact form
- Studio Administrator: Receives notification email with form submission data

3. Trigger
The feature is triggered when a website visitor clicks the "Absenden" (Submit) button on the contact form after completing all required fields.

4. Preconditions
- Contact form page is accessible and fully loaded
- All required form fields (name, email, message) are rendered in the DOM
- Backend API endpoint /api/contact exists and responds to POST requests
- Email service configuration is set for sending transactional emails
- Database table "contact_submissions" exists with required schema

5. Main Flow

1. Visitor navigates to the contact page at /kontakt
2. Visitor enters text into the "Name" input field (required)
3. Visitor enters text into the "E-Mail" input field (required)
4. Visitor enters text into the "Telefon" input field (optional)
5. Visitor selects an option from the "Betreff" dropdown menu (optional): "Allgemeine Anfrage", "Kursanmeldung", "Probestunde", "Sonstiges"
6. Visitor enters text into the "Nachricht" textarea field (required)
7. Visitor clicks the "Absenden" button
8. JavaScript validation executes: checks that "Name" field contains at least 2 characters
9. JavaScript validation executes: checks that "E-Mail" field matches email regex pattern
10. JavaScript validation executes: checks that "Nachricht" field contains at least 10 characters
11. If any validation fails, JavaScript displays inline error messages under respective fields and stops execution
12. If validation passes, JavaScript disables the submit button and shows a loading indicator
13. JavaScript sends HTTP POST request to endpoint /api/contact with JSON payload containing: name, email, phone, subject, message, timestamp
14. Backend receives POST request at /api/contact
15. Backend validates request payload: ensures all required fields are present and non-empty
16. Backend sanitizes all string inputs using HTML entity encoding to prevent XSS attacks
17. Backend validates email format using RFC 5322 compliant regex
18. Backend inserts a new record into the "contact_submissions" table with columns: id (UUID), name, email, phone, subject, message, created_at (UTC timestamp), status (default: "new")
19. Database returns successful insert confirmation with the new record ID
20. Backend triggers asynchronous email to visitor's email address with subject "Ihre Anfrage an das Yoga Studio" containing form submission confirmation
21. Backend triggers asynchronous email to studio administrator at admin@yogastudio.local with subject "Neue Kontaktanfrage" containing full submission details
22. Backend returns HTTP 200 status code with JSON response: { "success": true, "message": "Nachricht erfolgreich gesendet", "submissionId": "<uuid>" }
23. Frontend receives HTTP 200 response
24. Frontend displays success message "Vielen Dank für Ihre Nachricht! Wir werden uns in Kürze bei Ihnen melden." in a green success banner
25. Frontend clears all form input fields
26. Frontend re-enables the submit button
27. Main flow ends

6. Alternate Flows

**Alternate Flow 1: Invalid Email Format**
1-11. Execute steps 1-11 from Main Flow
12. Visitor enters "invalid-email" in the E-Mail field
13. JavaScript validation fails email format check
14. JavaScript displays error message "Bitte geben Sie eine gültige E-Mail-Adresse ein" under the E-Mail field
15. Submit button remains enabled
16. Flow ends without form submission

**Alternate Flow 2: Backend Server Error**
1-13. Execute steps 1-13 from Main Flow
14. Backend encounters database connection failure
15. Backend returns HTTP 500 status code with JSON response: { "success": false, "message": "Ein Fehler ist aufgetreten. Bitte versuchen Sie es später erneut." }
16. Frontend displays error message in a red alert banner
17. Frontend retains all form data entered by visitor
18. Frontend re-enables the submit button
19. Flow ends

**Alternate Flow 3: Network Timeout**
1-13. Execute steps 1-13 from Main Flow
14. Request times out after 30 seconds due to network issues
15. Frontend catches timeout error
16. Frontend displays error message "Verbindung fehlgeschlagen. Bitte überprüfen Sie Ihre Internetverbindung und versuchen Sie es erneut."
17. Frontend retains all form data
18. Frontend re-enables the submit button
19. Flow ends

7. Postconditions

**Question 1: Identify the top unresolved product scope risk.**

Answer:
Die kritischste offene Scope-Risiko ist die architektonische Inkonsistenz zwischen den **System Boundaries** ("Kein eigenes Backend, Server-seitige Logik oder Datenbank") und dem Feature **F-05 (Contact Form Submission)**, welches explizit ein Backend mit API-Endpunkt `/api/contact`, Datenbank-Tabelle `contact_submissions` und serverseitige Verarbeitung beschreibt. Dieser Widerspruch führt zu technischer Fragmentierung, unklaren Verantwortlichkeiten und potenzieller Budgetüberschreitung.

Reasoning:
Eine gemischte Architektur (statisches Frontend + eigenes Backend) verdoppelt die Komplexität, erfordert Server-Management, Datenbank-Backups, Security-Patching und umfangreiche GDPR-Compliance-Maßnahmen (Protokollierung, Löschkonzept). Für ein Yogastudio-Landingpage-Projekt mit Fokus auf "Serverless" und "Low Maintenance" ist dies Anti-Pattern. Die Entscheidung muss absolut sein: Entweder Full-Static mit Managed Services (Netlify Forms/Formspree) oder Full-Stack mit Backend – eine Mischform erzeugt technische Schulden.

Concrete Implementation:
Section: **System Boundaries** → Subsection "Nicht im System enthalten (Out-of-Scope)" erweitern um:
"Serverless Functions, Edge Functions oder eigene Backend-APIs zur Formularverarbeitung; Datenbank-Systeme jeglicher Art. Formularverarbeitung ausschließlich über Drittanbieter-SaaS (Netlify Forms, Formspree) im Zero-Backend-Ansatz."

Section: **Functional Feature Catalogue** → F-05 "Contact Form Submission" komplett entfernen und inhaltlich in **F-04** integrieren. F-04 neu definieren als:
"F-04: Kontaktformular-Integration (Managed Service) – Client-seitige Validierung mit Submission an Netlify Forms oder Formspree; keine serverseitige Persistenz auf eigener Infrastruktur."

**Question 2: Identify the top unresolved UX risk.**

Answer:
Das größte UX-Risiko ist das Fehlen definierter **Loading States und Error Boundaries** für das client-seitige Rendering des Kursplans (F-03), insbesondere bei langsamen Mobilfunkverbindungen (3G) oder JSON-Ladefehlern. Ohne explizite Skeleton Screens und Retry-Mechanismen entsteht ein "Flash of Unstyled Content" (FOUC) oder eine leere Sektion, die Nutzer als "Seite defekt" wahrnehmen (Abbruchrate steigt um bis zu 40%).

Reasoning:
Da der Kursplan aus einer externen JSON-Datei (`/data/schedule.json`) gerendert wird, existiert eine asynchrone Lücke zwischen DOM-Ready und Datenverfügbarkeit. Screenreader-Nutzer erhalten keine Rückmeldung über Ladezustände. Eine klare Loading-Strategie (Skeleton → Content → Error-State) ist essenziell für WCAG 2.1 AA Konformität (Statusmeldungen) und Core Web Vitals (CLS-Vermeidung).

Concrete Implementation:
Section: **F-03: Kursplan** → UI-Impact erweitern um:
"**Ladezustände:** Skeleton-Screen mit 5 pulsierenden Platzhalter-Karten (CSS-Animation `pulse 2s infinite`) während des JSON-Fetch. ARIA live-Region mit `aria-live="polite"` für Ankündigung 'Kursplan wird geladen' an Screenreader."

### F-02: Services Overview Section

1. Purpose
The purpose of the Services Overview Section is to inform website visitors about the yoga offerings available at the studio. This section displays a curated list of services with titles and descriptions, enabling potential customers to understand the studio's value proposition and determine which offerings align with their needs. - **Secondary Actor**: Content Administrator (studio owner or staff who manages the website content)

  1. Hatha Yoga: "Sanfte Körperarbeit für Anfänger und Fortgeschrittene. Improve flexibility and inner peace through traditional postures."
  2. Vinyasa Flow: "Dynamischer Yoga-Stil mit fließenden Bewegungen. Synchronize breath with movement for increased strength."

### F-03: Course Schedule Display

The Course Schedule Display feature presents a structured overview of all available yoga classes at the studio. ### F-05: Contact Form Submission

1. Purpose
The contact form submission feature enables website visitors to send inquiries to the yoga studio. It captures visitor contact information and message content, validates the input, stores the submission in the backend database, and triggers confirmation emails to both the visitor and the studio administrator. This facilitates lead generation and customer communication.

2. Actors
- Website Visitor: Fills out and submits the contact form
- Studio Administrator: Receives notification email with form submission data

3. Trigger
The feature is triggered when a website visitor clicks the "Absenden" (Submit) button on the contact form after completing all required fields.

4. Preconditions
- Contact form page is accessible and fully loaded
- All required form fields (name, email, message) are rendered in the DOM
- Backend API endpoint /api/contact exists and responds to POST requests
- Email service configuration is set for sending transactional emails
- Database table "contact_submissions" exists with required schema

5. Main Flow

1. Visitor navigates to the contact page at /kontakt
2. Visitor enters text into the "Name" input field (required)
3. Visitor enters text into the "E-Mail" input field (required)
4. Visitor enters text into the "Telefon" input field (optional)
5. Visitor selects an option from the "Betreff" dropdown menu (optional): "Allgemeine Anfrage", "Kursanmeldung", "Probestunde", "Sonstiges"
6. Visitor enters text into the "Nachricht" textarea field (required)
7. Visitor clicks the "Absenden" button
8. JavaScript validation executes: checks that "Name" field contains at least 2 characters
9. JavaScript validation executes: checks that "E-Mail" field matches email regex pattern
10. JavaScript validation executes: checks that "Nachricht" field contains at least 10 characters
11. If any validation fails, JavaScript displays inline error messages under respective fields and stops execution
12. If validation passes, JavaScript disables the submit button and shows a loading indicator
13. JavaScript sends HTTP POST request to endpoint /api/contact with JSON payload containing: name, email, phone, subject, message, timestamp
14. Backend receives POST request at /api/contact
15. Backend validates request payload: ensures all required fields are present and non-empty
16. Backend sanitizes all string inputs using HTML entity encoding to prevent XSS attacks
17. Backend validates email format using RFC 5322 compliant regex
18. Backend inserts a new record into the "contact_submissions" table with columns: id (UUID), name, email, phone, subject, message, created_at (UTC timestamp), status (default: "new")
19. Database returns successful insert confirmation with the new record ID
20. Backend triggers asynchronous email to visitor's email address with subject "Ihre Anfrage an das Yoga Studio" containing form submission confirmation
21. Backend triggers asynchronous email to studio administrator at admin@yogastudio.local with subject "Neue Kontaktanfrage" containing full submission details
22. Backend returns HTTP 200 status code with JSON response: { "success": true, "message": "Nachricht erfolgreich gesendet", "submissionId": "<uuid>" }
23. Frontend receives HTTP 200 response
24. Frontend displays success message "Vielen Dank für Ihre Nachricht! Wir werden uns in Kürze bei Ihnen melden." in a green success banner
25. Frontend clears all form input fields
26. Frontend re-enables the submit button
27. Main flow ends

6. Alternate Flows

**Alternate Flow 1: Invalid Email Format**
1-11. Execute steps 1-11 from Main Flow
12. Visitor enters "invalid-email" in the E-Mail field
13. JavaScript validation fails email format check
14. JavaScript displays error message "Bitte geben Sie eine gültige E-Mail-Adresse ein" under the E-Mail field
15. Submit button remains enabled
16. Flow ends without form submission

**Alternate Flow 2: Backend Server Error**
1-13. Execute steps 1-13 from Main Flow
14. Backend encounters database connection failure
15. Backend returns HTTP 500 status code with JSON response: { "success": false, "message": "Ein Fehler ist aufgetreten. Bitte versuchen Sie es später erneut." }
16. Frontend displays error message in a red alert banner
17. Frontend retains all form data entered by visitor
18. Frontend re-enables the submit button
19. Flow ends

**Alternate Flow 3: Network Timeout**
1-13. Execute steps 1-13 from Main Flow
14. Request times out after 30 seconds due to network issues
15. Frontend catches timeout error
16. Frontend displays error message "Verbindung fehlgeschlagen. Bitte überprüfen Sie Ihre Internetverbindung und versuchen Sie es erneut."
17. Frontend retains all form data
18. Frontend re-enables the submit button
19. Flow ends

7. Postconditions

- Confirmation email has been queued for delivery to the visitor's email address
